      <div id="readme" class="blob instapaper_body">
    <article class="markdown-body entry-content" itemprop="mainContentOfPage"><p></p> <h2>
<a name="user-content-regression-models---week-4" class="anchor" href="#regression-models---week-4" aria-hidden="true"><span class="octicon octicon-link"></span></a>Regression Models - Week 4</h2> 
 <h3>
<a name="user-content----------------------------------------" class="anchor" href="#---------------------------------------" aria-hidden="true"><span class="octicon octicon-link"></span></a>---------------------------------------</h3> 

<h4>
<a name="user-content-video-41---generalized-linear-models" class="anchor" href="#video-41---generalized-linear-models" aria-hidden="true"><span class="octicon octicon-link"></span></a><em>Video 4.1 - Generalized Linear Models</em>
</h4>

<p><strong>A. Linear Models</strong></p>

<ul>
<li>Linear models have limitations

<ul>
<li>Additive response models don't make much sense if the response is discrete or strictly positive</li>
<li>Transformations are hard to interpret</li>
<li>There's value to modeling the data on the scale that it was collected</li>
<li>Some transformations aren't applicable for negative or zero values</li>
</ul>
</li>
</ul><p><strong>B. GLM</strong></p>

<ul>
<li>Three components

<ul>
<li>Exponential family model for the response</li>
<li>Systematic component via  linear predictor</li>
<li>A link function that connects the means of the response to the linear predictor</li>
</ul>
</li>
</ul><h4>
<a name="user-content-video-42---glm-examples" class="anchor" href="#video-42---glm-examples" aria-hidden="true"><span class="octicon octicon-link"></span></a><em>Video 4.2 - GLM Examples</em>
</h4>

<p><strong>A. Example, linear models</strong></p>

<ul>
<li>The Gaussian distribution is an exponential family distribution</li>
</ul><p><strong>B. Example, Logistic Regression</strong></p>

<ul>
<li>Given, say, Bernoulli data</li>
<li>The mean is between 0 and 1</li>
<li>The link function is the logit transformation --&gt; log \frac{\mu}{1-\mu}</li>
<li>Logit = "log of the odds"</li>
<li>You can invert the logit using exponentials</li>
<li>Likelihood given by bernoulli likelihood function</li>
</ul><p><strong>C. Example, POisson Regression</strong></p>

<h4>
<a name="user-content-video-43---variances-and-quasi-likelihood" class="anchor" href="#video-43---variances-and-quasi-likelihood" aria-hidden="true"><span class="octicon octicon-link"></span></a><em>Video 4.3 - Variances and Quasi Likelihood</em>
</h4>

<p><strong>A. Some Things to Note</strong></p>

<ul>
<li>THe likelihood only needs that x's and y's</li>
<li>All models achieve their maximum at the root of the so-called normal equations</li>
</ul><p><strong>B. About Variances</strong></p>

<ul>
<li>For the linear model, var(Y) = sigma^2^</li>
<li>For Bernoulli Var(Yi)=ui(1-ui)</li>
<li>For poisson, var(Yi) = ui</li>
<li>It may be relevant to have a more flexible variance model, even if it doesn't correspond to actual likelihood ("quasi-likelihood")

<ul>
<li>relaxes the assumptions about relationship between mean and variance</li>
</ul>
</li>
</ul><p><strong>C. Odds and Ends</strong></p>

<ul>
<li>The normal equations have to be solved iteratively</li>
<li>Coefficients are interpreted on the link-function scale</li>
<li>Asympntotics are used for inference, usually</li>
<li>Many of the ideas from linear models can be brought over to GLMs</li>
</ul><h4>
<a name="user-content-video-44---glms-binary-data" class="anchor" href="#video-44---glms-binary-data" aria-hidden="true"><span class="octicon octicon-link"></span></a><em>Video 4.4 - GLMs, binary data</em>
</h4>

<p><strong>A. Key Ideas</strong></p>

<ul>
<li>We care about outcomes with two values (success vs failure)</li>
<li>Binary, Bernoulli, or 0/1 outcomes</li>
<li>Collection of exchangeable binary outcomes for the same covariate data are called binomial outcomes</li>
</ul><p><strong>B. Linear Regression, Ravens Win/Loss Data</strong></p>

<ul>
<li>Linear model could result in values outside of the 0/1 range</li>
<li>Logistic regression would use the logit transformation to give potentially better estimates</li>
</ul><p><strong>C. Interpreting Logistic Regression</strong></p>

<ul>
<li>exp(b1) - odds ratio of win probability for each point scored (compared to 0 points)</li>
</ul><h4>
<a name="user-content-video-45---glms-and-odds" class="anchor" href="#video-45---glms-and-odds" aria-hidden="true"><span class="octicon octicon-link"></span></a><em>Video 4.5 - GLMs and odds</em>
</h4>

<p><strong>A. Odds</strong></p>

<ul>
<li>The odds can be said as "how much should you be willing to pay for a <em>p</em> probability of winning a dollar?"</li>
<li>Log odds is the canonical link for the Bernoulli GLM</li>
<li>probability:</li>
</ul><pre><code>exp(beta0 + beta1*x)/(1+ exp(beta0 + beta1 * x))
</code></pre>

<ul>
<li>As beta gets closer to 0, the logit curve flattens out</li>
<li>If beta is exactly 0, the curve is perfectly horizontal</li>
<li>For different values of Xs, we have Ys that are 0 or 1</li>
<li>Uses binomial likelihood to fit a curve through a set of 0s and 1s</li>
</ul><p><strong>B. R Code for Logistic Regression</strong></p>

<div class="highlight highlight-r"><pre>logRegRavens <span class="o">&lt;-</span> glm<span class="p">(</span>ravensData<span class="o">$</span>ravenWinNum <span class="o">~</span> ravensData<span class="o">$</span>ravenScore<span class="p">,</span> family <span class="o">=</span> <span class="s">"binomial"</span><span class="p">)</span>
</pre></div>

<ul>
<li>The intercept is the log odds of the ravens winning when they score nothing</li>
<li>Take e^coefficient^ for odds</li>
<li>e^x^ looks like 1 + x for x near 0</li>
<li>Just like with linear regression, the intercept is an extrapolation. IF you have no data near it, don't interpret it too seriously</li>
<li>Probability --&gt; See line beginning with exp() above</li>
</ul><h4>
<a name="user-content-video-46---more-on-odds" class="anchor" href="#video-46---more-on-odds" aria-hidden="true"><span class="octicon octicon-link"></span></a><em>Video 4.6 - More on Odds</em>
</h4>

<p><strong>A. ANOVA for logistic regression</strong></p>

<div class="highlight highlight-r"><pre>anova<span class="p">(</span>logRegRavens<span class="p">,</span> test<span class="o">=</span><span class="s">"Chisq"</span><span class="p">)</span>
</pre></div>

<ul>
<li>Tests the difference between residual deviances from two models</li>
<li>Take a smaller model and subtract a larger model from it</li>
<li>DF = number of additional parameters</li>
<li>The difference in residual variances is Chi-Squared distributed</li>
</ul><p><strong>B. Interpreting Odds Ratios</strong></p>

<ul>
<li>Not probabilities</li>
<li>Odds ratio of 1 = no difference in odds</li>
<li>Log odds ratio of 0 = no difference in odds</li>
<li>odds ratio &lt; 0.5 or &gt; 2 commonly a "moderate effect"</li>
<li>Relative risk is often easier to interpret, but harder to estimate</li>
<li>for small probabilities, relative risk is roughly equal to the odds ratio</li>
<li>Relative risk models are capped at 0, creating some boundary issues</li>
<li>Odds have an interesting use in retrospective studies (say, looking back at how people lived and comparing outcomes between groups)</li>
<li>Odds can be used to turn retrospective findings into a prospective claim</li>
</ul><p><strong>C. Further Resources</strong></p>

<ul>
<li>Wikipedia is pretty good</li>
<li>Logistic regression and glms in R</li>
<li>Brian Caffo's lecture notes on: Simpson's paradox, case-control studies</li>
</ul><h4>
<a name="user-content-video-47---poisson-regression" class="anchor" href="#video-47---poisson-regression" aria-hidden="true"><span class="octicon octicon-link"></span></a><em>Video 4.7 - Poisson Regression</em>
</h4>

<p><strong>A. Key Ideas</strong></p>

<ul>
<li>Many data take the form of counts

<ul>
<li>call to a call center, disease incidence
-Data may also be in the form of rates</li>
<li>Percent of children passing a test</li>
<li>Percent of hits to a website from a country</li>
<li>rate = count per unit of time (per "monitoring time")</li>
</ul>
</li>
<li>Linear regression with transformation is an option</li>
<li>precents are better in poisson (vs. binomial) when sample size is large and probability is very low</li>
</ul><p><strong>B. Poisson Distribution</strong></p>

<ul>
<li>Poisson distribution is a useful model for counts and rates</li>
<li>Here a rate is count per some monitoring time</li>
<li>Analyzing contingency table data

<ul>
<li>COntingency table is basically a cross tabe</li>
</ul>
</li>
<li>see slide on Poisson mass function</li>
<li>Variance is equal to the mean</li>
<li>Poisson tends toward normal as t gets large</li>
<li>\lambda is interpreted as "expected counts per time"</li>
</ul><h4>
<a name="user-content-video-48---example-leek-group-website-traffic" class="anchor" href="#video-48---example-leek-group-website-traffic" aria-hidden="true"><span class="octicon octicon-link"></span></a><em>Video 4.8 - Example: Leek Group Website Traffic</em>
</h4>

<p><strong>A. Beginning</strong></p>

<ul>
<li>Consider daily counts to Jeff Leek's website</li>
<li>The count you get is some combination of lambda and t (monitoring time)</li>
<li>julian() days are numbers tha can be worked with programmatically

<ul>
<li>julian() dates are measure of time since a specific data in days</li>
</ul>
</li>
</ul><p><strong>B. Aside, taking the log of the outcome</strong></p>

<ul>
<li>Taking the natural log of the outcome has a specific interpretation</li>
</ul><p><strong>C. Exponentiating Coefficients</strong></p>

<ul>
<li>When you take the natural log of outcomes and fit a regression model, your exponentiated coefficients estimate things about geometric means</li>
<li>There's a problem with logs when you have zero counts, but adding a constant generally works</li>
<li>Geometric mean is more appropriate for some collection of % increases or decreases</li>
<li>because we're dealing with geometric (multiplicative) means, a coefficient beta1 of 1.002 says "a 0.2% increase per day"</li>
</ul><p><strong>D. Linear vs. Poisson Regression</strong></p>

<ul>
<li>In poisson regression, the expected value is the exponential of the right hand side</li>
<li>Poisson = "log-lin"</li>
</ul><p><strong>E. Multiplicative Differences</strong></p>

<ul>
<li>Expected value of LHS is the exponential of RHS</li>
</ul><h4>
<a name="user-content-video-49---poisson-rate-models" class="anchor" href="#video-49---poisson-rate-models" aria-hidden="true"><span class="octicon octicon-link"></span></a><em>Video 4.9 - Poisson Rate Models</em>
</h4>

<p><strong>A. POisson Regression</strong></p>

<pre><code>glm1 &lt;- glm(gaData$visit ~ gaData$julian, family="poisson")
</code></pre>

<p><strong>B. Mean-Variance Relationship?</strong></p>

<ul>
<li>GLM residuals are a sort of "generalized" residual</li>
<li>With poisson, you expect variation to be increasing with the mean</li>
<li>One way to address this is using robust standard errors</li>
<li>You caould also try family = "quasi Poisson" which adjusts the variance to be the mean * some factor</li>
<li>You can also use the model-agnostic standard erorrs from the <code>sandwich</code> package</li>
</ul><p><strong>C. Rates</strong></p>

<ul>
<li>What if, for exapmle, you want to model the proportion of hits to Leek Group specifically from Simply Statistics?</li>
<li>Model the log count from SS and put an "offset" for the denominator (total hits) on the RHS</li>
<li>If you put in an offset, the mean is now relative to that offset</li>
</ul><div class="highlight highlight-r"><pre>glm2 <span class="o">&lt;-</span> glm<span class="p">(</span>gaData<span class="o">$</span>simplystats <span class="o">~</span> <span class="kp">julian</span><span class="p">(</span>gaData<span class="o">$</span><span class="kp">date</span><span class="p">),</span> offset<span class="o">=</span><span class="kp">log</span><span class="p">(</span>visits<span class="m">+1</span><span class="p">),</span> family<span class="o">=</span><span class="s">"poisson"</span><span class="p">,</span> data<span class="o">=</span>gaData<span class="p">)</span>
</pre></div>

<ul>
<li>visits + 1 used because visits have 0s in them</li>
<li>an offset does not have a coefficient</li>
<li>Make the offset log of whatever you want to be in the denominator of your rate equation</li>
<li>The wikipedia discussion on overdispersion and poisson regression are useful</li>
<li>Consider the <code>pscl</code> package and zeroinfl() function to deal with zero-inflation

<ul>
<li>Zero inflation is the case when you have more zeros in your data that you'd expect</li>
<li>an example might be that you have more zeros in the early stages of your dataset that you might want</li>
</ul>
</li>
</ul><h4>
<a name="user-content-video-410---fitting-functions" class="anchor" href="#video-410---fitting-functions" aria-hidden="true"><span class="octicon octicon-link"></span></a><em>Video 4.10 - Fitting Functions</em>
</h4>

<p><strong>A. How to fit functions using Linear Models</strong></p>

<ul>
<li>We're trying to fit some function using linear models</li>
<li>You could use dummies for "knot points"</li>
<li>The function is still continuous at these knot points</li>
<li>New intercept + slope every time you hit a new "knot point"</li>
</ul><p><strong>B. Simulated Example</strong></p>

<ul>
<li>Adding squared terms makes it continuously differentiable at the knot points</li>
<li>Adding cubic terms makes it twice continuously differentiable at the knot points; etc.</li>
</ul><p><strong>C. Notes</strong></p>

<ul>
<li>The collection of spline regressors is called a basis

<ul>
<li>People have spent a lot of time thinking about bases for this kind of problem</li>
</ul>
</li>
<li>Single knot point terms can fit hockey stick like processes</li>
<li>These bases can be used in GLMs as well</li>
<li>An issue with these approaches is the large number of parameter introduced

<ul>
<li>Requires some method of so-called regularization</li>
</ul>
</li>
</ul><h4>
<a name="user-content-video-411---a-fun-exmple" class="anchor" href="#video-411---a-fun-exmple" aria-hidden="true"><span class="octicon octicon-link"></span></a><em>Video 4.11 - A Fun Exmple</em>
</h4>

<p><strong>A. Harmonics using linear models</strong></p>

<ul>
<li>One famous set of orthogonal bases is sin &amp; cosine transformations</li>
<li>You can play notes into R and have it guess what chords you're playing</li>
</ul></article>
